awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Probing and Controlling Binding Structure and Electron Transport in Molecular Electronic Devices--A Coordinated Computational and Experimental Study
awd_abstract_narration:
Abstract:

Non-Technical:
Molecular electronics started with the idea of wiring an individual molecule to two metal electrodes, called single-molecule junctions, as an analogy of single electronic components in commercial microelectronic devices to overcome the limit of famous Moore's prediction. In a single molecular junction, perhaps the most elusive factor that influences the electron transport properties lies in the molecule-electrode contact interfaces. Despite continuous experimental achievements and the conceptual simplicity of molecular electronic devices, challenges for their theoretical understanding of the correlation between electron transport and molecular binding structures are still unresolved. Therefore, probing and controlling the structure and dynamics of single-molecule junctions and consequently controlling the molecular transport of these junctions are critical to the development of this field. The project will integrate molecular simulations for the self-assembly and nanocontact dynamics at surface and interface, and experimental mechanics and electron transport measurements of single-molecule junctions. The project will provide a deep understanding of many transition phenomena observed in molecular force and conductance measurements. If successful, the research will have tremendous impact on molecular electronics community and many other areas, such as energy research and molecular force spectroscopy. The education and outreach objective of this proposal is to tightly integrate the research efforts and results with graduate, undergraduate, and K-12 education and to globally disseminate both research and the education outcomes.
Technical:
Although the electrical conductance and mechanical properties of single-molecule junctions have achieved significant progress over the past decade, challenges of a detailed understanding of molecular binding structures and electron transport, and the structure-force-conductance correlations, are still unresolved. This research will develop a combined molecular simulation and scanning probe microscope break-junction technique to probe and control the structure and dynamics in molecular electronics devices: (1) Performing molecular simulations by using as close as possible the experimental parameters, dynamics of electrode and realistic atomic interactions to understand the binding structure and force measurement in scanning probe experiment; (2) Developing a dual-mode feedback system with AC-coupled high speed amplifier at radio frequency to capture the key transitions of molecular binding sites that induce conductance changes. The experimental data at nanosecond (ns) timescale will be directly compared with molecular simulation results; (3) Using the coordinated molecular simulation and scanning probe break-junction experiment to probe the structure and dynamics of selected benchmark systems under different mode trainings. Multi-variable force-conductance two-dimensional cross-correlation histogram analyses for the force and conductance traces will be performed in experiments and simulations, and the distinct stable configurations of molecular junctions will be identified. The coordinated computational and experimental research project will also provide an interdisciplinary research for students in materials, mechanics, chemistry, electronics, and computational materials science.

por.por_cntn:
The concept of molecular electronics was proposed almost 40 years ago and with the fast approach physical limit silicon-based materials and devices, molecular electronics lifted to the top priority. For, molecular electronics aims at developing molecular devices that will complement – and eventually even supersede – current semiconductor-based technologies. The widely adopted molecular transport junction techniques, where single or a few molecules were sandwiched between two electrodes, have unique advantages due to their hybrid solid state-molecular nature, which provides ample “knobs” to control the transport properties. Despite recent significant experimental and theoretical progress in measuring and understanding the electrical conductance and mechanical properties of single molecule junctions, challenges of understanding of molecular binding structures and electron transport, and the structure-force-conductance correlations, are still unresolved. The project tackles these challenges by developing a combined molecular simulation and experimental technique to establish a foundation for the computational and experimental studies of the molecular electronics devices. Experimentally, we apply our recent development of single molecule scanning probe microscope (SPM) molecular transport junction (MTJ) system to measure the conductance and force under precise controls the spatial and time variables so as to probe and control the structure and dynamics of single molecular junctions in molecular electronics devices and provide a detailed and in-depth understanding of electronic transport, finding viable “knobs” to control the transport properties in molecular junction nanocircuits.

In the three-and-half years (including a half year NCE in the 4th year) of the project, our results obtained from this award underscore the importance of probing and controlling the structure and dynamics of single molecular junctions in molecular electronics devices. Our work on developing a highly-integrated SPM-based experimental platform and more advanced data processing algorithms demonstrates that the detailed electron transport properties of single-molecule junction devices hidden in the experimental data can be unraveled. This platform is also the technical support to tackle problems associated with electron transport through DNA molecular devices. Our work on studying side-group-mediated mechanical conductance switching in molecular junctions demonstrated a single molecule electromechanical switch, which can be between two conductance states by repeated compression and elongation to control the molecule–electrode coupling strength and contact geometry. This represents a significant expansion of the single molecule electronics “tool-box” for the design of junctions with electromechanical properties. In studying the quantum interference features charge transport in metal–molecule–metal junctions, we realized constructive quantum interference features in the transmission profile (Fano resonances) pinned to the electrode Fermi level, which arise upon complexation. This approach charts a clear path for the fabrication of molecular devices with some of the most desirable features, such as high conductance and long-range transport, with a high predicted efficiency in energy conversion. In addition to these proposed mechanical “knobs”, we excitedly discover a photonic (light) “knob” to control the electric switches. Firstly, we demonstrated a conductance switch of a symmetrical molecule junction under illumination, which is counterintuitive, based on the formation of bound excitons in the molecule. We not only established a new a mechanism for molecular photo conductance but provided a simple design principle for enhancing the performance of molecular switches. Then, we demonstrated that a conductance switch can be realized in metallic quantum contacts, bare electrodes without any molecules, greatly simplified system. Thus, the photo-controlled atomic switch may pave the way for the realization of highly integrated devices. Complimentary to molecular junction researches, the students and the PI also engaged in multi-institute international collaborations in study self-assembly of supramolecular fractals, an approach to generate new functional molecular materials. Work under this grant also contributed to 8 journal articles and a few additional papers either have been submitted or are near submission. Many of the published papers have appeared in top-tier journals, such as J. Am. Chem. Soc., Nat. Commun., and Angew. Chem. Int. Ed.

The fundamental understanding we have gained in the past 3.5 years with the correlation between electron transport and molecular binding structures has not only disclosed new insights into structure-dependent transport in molecular junctions by closing the conductance-force-structure loop for such novel junctions, but also led to improvements in detailed experimental controls and modulations of single-molecule junction devices, and more importantly, provide design principles for enhancing the performance of molecular junction device. The education, collaboration, and outreach of the PI has provided participants at undergraduate and graduate level the opportunities not only to learn new cutting-edge science and develop key technologies, but also build networks of collaborators and acquire the necessary key skills to work in an interdisciplinary environment. Funds from this proposal have also supported or partly supported the work of 1 postdoc fellow, 3 grad students (including 2 women), and 4 undergrad students (including 2 women). We are also grateful for our research collaborators (2 from US, 3 from UK, 3 from China and 1 from Israel) in publishing the collaborative work.
